>>69314510
This. I put on like 12kg in 2 months because of a medication I was put on (I was already overweight so this put me on the cusp of obesity) and it made me realise how awful my diet was and that it was just my good metabolism due to youth that let me only reach overweight status. I was 24 at the time and knew that my metabolism would slow past 25 and that things would only get worse, so I started doing an hour of exercise 5 days a week (half an hour cardio, half an hour calisthenics), cut out all soda and goyslop, and used more whole foods and ingredients for what I still ate. This was enough to get me down 35kg and I’ve maintained my weight within a margin of 1kg up and down ever since. It’s really not that hard to lose weight and be moderately healthy, like it took effort but nowhere near as much as you expect it too before you start doing it. I think a lot of fatties are under the false assumption that you need to do bodybuilder tier exercise and diet to lose weight (I was one of them for the longest time) and use that to justify not trying to lose weight. There are also those who are just flat out deluded, not misinformed like most. It’s really fucked up that basic nutrition and health aren’t taught in schools, now that I actually know what I’m doing it’s easy as piss and I’m mad that I wasted 24 years as a fatty when it was so easy not to be.

>>69306990
>he said something i dont like
>call him a zoomer
Supposedly contradictory results are from different methods, different measurements and different study populations.
All the "opposites" you're thinking of are from observational studies that aren't actually testing anything, they're just tracking different populations over time and trying to find correlations between diet + health outcomes. By the law of statistics you're always going to find patterns in every study that appear to be relevant, but we repeat the study, and 95% of the time it disappears.
Disregarding the epistemological basis of our reality because there are some poor-quality health studies is a massive brainlet move, and you're just outing yourself as too fucking stupid to discern which studies are high quality and which ones aren't.
If it isn't an RCT, it's got a 95% chance of being meaningless garbage.
If it's an RCT that hasn't been duplicated, it has a 50% chance of being meaningless garbage.

I've recently developed a new combo. You only need one grip for it.
So you start with a sleeve grip (elbow or above), you then have 2 options.
1. If your opponent has yet to get a grip, move back so they have to step forward to get a grip. The moment they step forward go for a drop seoi.
2. You have a grip and your opponent has a grip, go for an inside hook/ouchi gari.
Your opponent will most likely survive and that is fine. At that point you will then have to stomp. You stomp and your opponent will be tricked into thinking you're going for ouchi gari and will move back. Once they realise your attack was a fake, they'll relax and begin to move forward, at that point you go for a drop seoi.

I've caught a tonne of people out with this at my judo club and BJJ club.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I'm kinda autistic about my eating. I have 2 smaller meals in the evening instead of one. I'll split 5 or 6 softboiled eggs and a pound of ground beef between 2 meals, a smaller meal with carbs before I leave so I'm not bloated when I lift and a larger meal when I get home with veggies and a protein shake. It works out great, hits my macros, I love soft boiled eggs and I always have plenty of energy for the gym since I'm usually there for about 2 hours. I have a great butcher in my town that sells nice cheap fatty ground beef and eggs are as always a god tier protein source. I usually leave the other 2 meals loose since my work can make regular meals challenging.

>>69305449

It’s actually a really tricky question, because I’m quite sure no one knows the real answer to this.
However, based on my personal experience of experimenting with recovery, sleep & eating schedules, I’ve always found that fasting in the evening has incredibly positive results.
After a workout I don’t think it matters at all because your body isn’t resting or trying to heal itself, it’s just doing the day-to-day things it does while you stand, walk, work, drive etc. (though it’s interesting because you get really tired, almost like your body is saying “go to sleep motherfucker so I can fix this shit).
Once you’re sleeping though, that’s where the magic happens. I think the reason (with zero scientific evidence behind this theory) is that when you’re sleeping & fasting, your body can put all the resources it’s gathered during the day like proteins etc entirely towards recovery and it also has the maximum amount of time to repair things, and doesn’t have to carry out digestion, storing energy, separating chains, and so on.

Just my take though, I’m sure others have different experiences which is why this is so debated.

Pppppfffff wtf is this.

You absolutely can train to be faster.

If your cardio improves, that entails you are punching faster. Cardio is the ability for your body to pump blood to muscle tissue, thereby energizing it. You are telling me getting energy to your muscles more efficiently does not improve speed?

People punch slower as they get tired, so clearly if you improve your cardio, you will not get tired and in consequence you will punch faster.

People can get leaner. You are telling me that if someone get's leaner, and shaves off extra weight, they wont get faster?

Strength. You can get stronger. Strength is by definition the ability to exert force. You are telling me that if I got stronger, the extra force would not translate into additional speed?

This is all just the basics. A lot of speed training in striking is building up reflexes, which is a matter of training your nervous system. And clearly, people can learn reflexes (like they do when playing musical instruments, or typing on a computer).

Go back to r9k retard. Steroids are going to addict you and shut down natural test production. You don't even look bad. Your problem is you put too much focus on your body. Improve your life in other departments, while working out all the time as a supplement. Working out should be a supplement to your life, not your main hobby. Otherwise anyone who follows your way of life will end up like you - insecure and never happy with progress. If you focus on other aspects of your life while regularly working out you'll slowly, but surely build up a better body with no stress involved. It's the kind of thing that takes years, and there's many variables like height, genetic potential, limb length etc. that dictates how you look. Another important thing to consider is that it doesn't matter how you look like compared to Schwarzenegger, or some roided up TikTok star, what matters about your body is how you look like to people you hang around. You can mog average people with 1 year of progress. You can mog regular lifters with few years of progress. you'll likely never mog Schwarzenegger, but it's not like you are going to ever meet him + you can mog him in other departments of your life such as skills, job, money, fashion sense, house etc. So in general my point is that if you gymcel and do roids you'll be impressive only to other gymcels - at some point average people can't even recognize that you have this amount of muscles - you just look good and fit to them at a certain level, and after that point a normie can't tell a difference. For normies people who have many aspects of their lives developed are more impressive than some autist who engages only in one specific pursuit. It's good to have a "main" skill, but this skill should make you money, so you can have freedom to pursue many things at the same time. Gymcelling doesn't pay you, so don't do roids that will addict you, and shut down your test production - it's absolutely not worth it.

Squat 150x1 160x0

Hanging Leg Raise 5 sets

Reflections of a DYEL running Conjugate:
- Greed is the root of all evil; aim for a conservative PR
- Rotate in the main lifts frequently
- Do 2 accessory exercises, 30 to 50 reps spread across 3 to 5 sets
- Wave dynamic effort percentages (60-70%x1-3x8-12)
- Pause dynamic effort squats and bench presses

>Advice for new runners
- Try to keep your cadence high (at or around 180 steps per minute)
- Try to keep your heartrate in Zone1/2 (around an average of 55-65% of your max. heart rate)
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 mi. (10km), start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training routine for that race

We get many outcomes that are not desirable. We get many outcomes we *thought* were desirable and regret. We also get many shitty things that happen to us that turn out to be the best, most fulfilling things even though in the moment it’s just the worst. In simpler terms: we fuck up and get fucked up all the time. Overthink it and run out of batteries, hamster at the noggin wheel fully exhausted. However God is not wrong, and has never been wrong, although we are blind to the greater implications and consequences of where He leads, hence hindsight being 20/20. Think of every time you messed up and went "oh I shouldn’t have done that" but you did it anyway. This is not a failure on God's part; merely you choosing to not listen to the signs around you, listen to your gut, or just not not understanding. Nothing wrong with that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69316066
think of it this way. When you go to the gym do you just lift a dumbell continuously for hours without pause? No. That would be ridiculous. You do sets. So you take 5 moves then let your opponent take 5 moves. 1-2 minute break then repeat. Do this for 3-5 sets then change game. Do this for 4-5 different games but make sure you use a balanced variety of games. For example not chess then checkers. I’d choose something like this
>5x5 chess
>3x12 guess who
>4x10 connect 4
>4x10 monopoly
>15 minute cool down with a video game (cod, Fortnite etc)
3-5 days a week and you’re golden

Ignore all the manlets that are about to stay hating bro. I'll give whatever advice I can as a 6'5" former lanklet. I started lifting at 150 lbs, bulked up to max 260 lbs, currently 235 lbs, 225x2 ohp, 315x5 bench, 465x2 squat, 495x2 deadlift. Also not fat, can still do backflips and handstands. First normal weight gain for a tall guy is relative. 5lbs for you is like 1lb for an average height guy. You'll be gaining and losing 5lbs with a poop dude. Also 3000 isn't nearly enough calories for real gains. I was eating 7000 during my dirtiest bulk. Don't be afraid of gaining a little fat, with the extra height it's way less noticable.
Lastly start fucking lifting you pussy. Heavy as fuck compounds, also mix in calisthenics and maintain them during the bulk. Its way easier to keep calisthenics during a bulk then to start fresh at a heavy weight. And be insane about training core so you don't fuck your long ass spine. Look into the QL and train it, as well as abs and spinal erectors.

Yeah, the QL is massively neglected on most people, but it's not really noticeable on shorter people. I've gotten to the point where I have a 10 minute back routine I do everyday to stay healthy/pain free. Kneesovertoesguy has some great videos on the back.
Start lifting immediately, but keep doing calisthenics. Everyone likes to act like calisthenics are for beginners and then you graduate to weights, but that's not true at all. You need both. its actually not really dosage thats the problem its the delivery mechanism itself.
eg. if a normal vaccine gets into your blood stream the antigen can additional side effects , its usually nothing serious ,but can be for certain vaccines, which is why aspiration was the norm for a half a century or longer.

with the mrna lipid nano particle type, if it gets into your blood it can deposit the payload into any tissue in your body and cause an auto immune reaction, since its your own cells that are presenting the proteins, for most tissues this is no big deal, but if it happens to end up in a place like say , your heart, or your brain, and it becomes inflammed, it can be fatal or life changing.

this non-specific targeting of cells , is discussed in research papers on the technology and is considered one of the short comings. personally I think that should disqualify it for use in vaccine products, its fine for things like gene therapy or drugs delivery , but for antigen production , its just a bad idea, your asking for trouble.

>>69310751
The solution is not to stop feeling hungry; the sensation of hunger is the sensation of losing fat. The solution is to learn how to acknowledge hunger and allow it to pass. To experience the burning and not feel obligated to sate it.

If you are early in the cut (first 1-3 weeks), understand that you will feel less hungry by week 4.
If you have already been cutting for a month, you may be too obsessed with food. Extremely rigid dieting with intermittent fasting can cause you to become totally obsessed with eating, down to planning exactly what you will eat meals in advance.
If this is your case, allow yourself a snack when it feels right, taking the calories out of your largest meal. Don't allot exact calorie amounts for each meal, and give more flexibility to where/when you eat your daily calories. If you feel absolutely obligated to go 200 calories over, just go on a jog and consider it square.

I know you can overcome this because I see you've already overcome other incredible hurdles. It won't always be easy and it isn't meant to be easy. I personally am grateful for that. If I had everything easy who would I be? A douchebag probably giving out terrible advice on twitter while huffing my own farts. I'm grateful to have it hard because I'm grateful not to be that. You find your own story bro, I'm sure there's stuff you're grateful for even in these challenges.

also it shrinks your stomach over time, reducing appetite, you will get hungry at your usual feeding windows, but the longer the fast the less you eat so the more those get muffled, and you most likely will want to binge if you break it early, so be careful with that. That is correct. Mine is 2mg so I reconstitute with 2ml and then draw 0.2ml / 20 units (insulin needles sometimes say 'units') for 0.2mg for my daily injection. I would store in your fridge once reconstituted, or at least keep it away from light/heat. Yes unconstituted will last years. Definitely start on the lower end (I believe doctors recommend 0.5mg), otherwise prepared to get hit with GI distress and headaches. With my first few injections I got major flushing, minor headaches, and minor nausea. After a week I stopped getting those and am now on 1mg weekly without any issues. It's a very effective drug.

Your body reflects the behaviors and habits you do every day. The exercises other anons said are great, but the easiest way to make a difference is to consciously change your lifestyle.
I had terrible posture too, until I started working out and made a conscious effort to go outside, be more active socially, and play sports. Mindset makes a big difference as well. I had horrible depression and it physically scrunches your body over. Positive thoughts and confidence will reflect in your physical demeanor and vice versa. The mind is a powerful thing

posts.com:
>>69311944
Don’t listen to that guy. If your sleep is not maxed you are not going to have optimal test. You don’t necessarily need 8 hours, but if you aren’t getting close to that with little movement and steady low hr your sleep isn’t good enough. If you are eating more than 1 meal a week that isn’t real (fast food, microwave meals, etc) your diet isn’t good enough. If you aren’t getting sunlight/vitamin d you aren’t going to have optimal test. If you are using plastics for storing food instead of glass, if you are cooking with non stick pans instead of stainless or cast iron, if your cooking/eating utensils are not stainless or wooden, you will not be optimal test.

Bottom line is that healthy males in their 20s have the same testosterone on average as 50 year old men from a few decades ago. Some of that is to do with sedentary life/obesity, the rest is to do with endocrine disrupting chemicals in everything we use. These things are in your plastic water bottles, Tupperware, hell they are even in laundry detergents and receipts. Doctors will tell you your test is “normal” but it is only normal because statistically most people are at that level. 20 years ago it wasn’t the same. You have to change a lot in your life to optimize test.

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1454084/
>Discrepancy between self-reported and actual caloric intake and exercise in obese subjects
Background and methods: Some obese subjects repeatedly fail to lose weight even though they report restricting their caloric intake to less than 1200 kcal per day. We studied two explanations for this apparent resistance to diet--low total energy expenditure and underreporting of caloric intake--in 224 consecutive obese subjects presenting for treatment. Group 1 consisted of nine women and one man with a history of diet resistance in whom we evaluated total energy expenditure and its main thermogenic components and actual energy intake for 14 days by indirect calorimetry and analysis of body composition. Group 2, subgroups of which served as controls in the various evaluations, consisted of 67 women and 13 men with no history of diet resistance.

Results: Total energy expenditure and resting metabolic rate in the subjects with diet resistance (group 1) were within 5 percent of the predicted values for body composition, and there was no significant difference between groups 1 and 2 in the thermic effects of food and exercise. Low energy expenditure was thus excluded as a mechanism of self-reported diet resistance. In contrast, the subjects in group 1 underreported their actual food intake by an average (+/- SD) of 47 +/- 16 percent and overreported their physical activity by 51 +/- 75 percent. Although the subjects in group 1 had no distinct psychopathologic characteristics, they perceived a genetic cause for their obesity, used thyroid medication at a high frequency, and described their eating behavior as relatively normal (all P < 0.05 as compared with group 2).

Conclusions: The failure of some obese subjects to lose weight while eating a diet they report as low in calories is due to an energy intake substantially higher than reported and an overestimation of physical activity, not to an abnormality in thermogenesis.
